page.title: 17FLORA
page.content: The district lies on a small faulted area of carboniferous rock strata surrounded by calciferous sandstone. Because of these faults there is varied and interesting flora. Loch Libo,thought for many years to be the home of a very rare fern,{the } {crested buckler}(no longer seen),has instead the{tufted sage}as well as rare members of that and the Rush family.The shy but beautiful{butterfly {orchid}and the{lesser twayblade}can be seen. The woodland is mainly deciduous with the earliest trees being planted by Baron Mure of Caldwell in the treeless 18th century landscape. The beech-lined road to Neilston is his work too,though only one of his beeches remains in the main street of Uplawmoor.
